columns.text:
We have one bank offering a simple interest and the other bank offering a complex interest rate. 

We need to determine at what value of complex interest rate will generate the the same amount as the simple interest within the designated time span.

Before we proceed with the solution, let's first discuss the main difference between simple and compound interest rate.

**Simple interest rate** returns interest **only on principal amount**.

**Compound interest rate** returns interest **on every interest-increased amount**.

For example, $100 dollars principal payment at 50% interest rate (exaggerated for demonstration).

For simple interest rate, interest is $50 dollars. 

This means that every interest-increase period **total amount increases only by $50 every time**, meaning cash amounts will be $100, $150, $200 and so on.

For complex rate, principal is $100 dollars at 50% compound now. 

At first, total cash is $150. However, the next interest amount will be **50% of compounded amount, ie. 50% of $150**, which is $75, meaning the cash value will be $225. After that, next interest will be 50% of $225, and so on.

**Total value accrued by simple interest** can be presented using the formula:

$$\text{T}= \text{P}+(\text{P} \times \text{t} \times\text{r}_\text{s})$$

where:

$\text{T}$ = simple interest amount;\
$\text{P}$ = principal interest amount;\
$\text{t}$ = time passed;\
$\text{r}$ = simple interest (in decimals);

**Total value accrued by compound interest** is something we've encountered a lot in this chapter, only under a different name, **future value of single cash flow asset**:

$$\text{FV}= \text{P} \times (1+\text{r}_\text{c})^{\text{t}}$$

where:

$\text{FV}$ = future value;\
$\text{P}$ = principal interest amount;\
$\text{t}$ = time passed;\
$\text{r}_\text{c}$ = compound interest (in decimals);

What task essentially asks is 'what $\text{r}_{c}$ has to be in order for $\text{T}$ = $\text{FV}$'. To find that out, let's look at the values the task gives us.

 
| Particulars| Amounts| 
|:--:|:--:| 
| Simple interest rate|6.4% = 0.064 | 
| Total time passed | 10 years |

Before inserting the numerical values, let's first equate the two equations and see what we'll get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{T}=\text{FV}\\[10pt]
\text{P}+\text{P} \times \text{t} \times\text{r}_\text{s}&= \text{P} \times (1+\text{r}_\text{c})^{\text{t}}\\
\end{aligned}$$

All that remains now is to insert the numerical values from the table above:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{r}_\text{c}&=\left[(1+ \text{t} \times\text{r}_\text{s}\right)^\frac{1}{\text{t}}]-1\\[10pt]
&=\left[(1+ 10\times 0.064\right)^\frac{1}{\text{10}})]1\\[10pt]
&=1.0507-1\\[10pt]
&=0.0507\\[10pt]
&=\boxed{5.07\%}
\end{aligned}$$
In this question, it has been asked to determine the rate that should be set by the First Complex bank in order to match the First Simple Bank with regards to its investment in the coming $10$ years.

It is important to note here the difference between the **simple interest and the compound interest**. The basic difference between the two is the principle on which the interest is calculated. 

 In the case of simple interest, the interest is calculated on the **original principle**. This earned interest is not again invested. So, this interest is always calculated on the original principal.

In the case of compound interest, initially, the interest is calculated on the original principal. This earned interest is again invested (one gets **interest even on interest**). So, in the next period, the interest will be calculated on the sum of the original principal and the interest thereon.

The simple interest is calculated in the following manner:

$$\text{SI=P $\times$ R $\times$ T}$$

where $SI$ is the simple interest,

$P$ is the principal amount, 

$R$ is the interest rate, and

$T$ is the time period.

The amount after adding compound interest is calculated in the following manner:

$$\text{A=P $\left(1+r\right)^t$}$$

where $A$ is the amount after interest i.e. the future value,

$P$ is the principal amount, 

$r$ is the interest rate, and

$t$ is the time period.

The next step is to identify the given information:
|**Particulars** | **First Simple Bank** | **First Complex Bank**| 
|--|--|--| 
|Time Period |10 years |10 years | 
|Interest Type |Simple |Compound (Annually)| 
| Interest rate|6.4% |?|

Let the amount invested in the first simple bank be $\$100$. We will calculate the simple interest earned over a period of ten years by using the formula in step 3:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{SI}&=\$100\times0.064 \times10\\
&=\$64
\end{aligned}$$

Thus the amount of interest offered by the First Simple Bank is $\$64$.

After $10$ years the amount in the account will be the sum total of the principle and the interest. Accordingly,

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Amount}&=\$100+\$64\\
&=\$164
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, after $10$ years the amount in the First Simple Bank account will be $\$164$

Let us now consider that the same amount i.e. $\$100$ is invested in the First Complex Bank. 

Now, the First Complex Bank wants to match the amount offered by the First Simple Bank. So we will substitute $A=\$164$ in the compound interest formula in step 4 and then calculate the interest rate. Accordingly, 

$$\begin{aligned}
\$164&=\$100 \left(1+r\right)^{10}\\
\frac{\$164}{\$100}&=\left(1+r\right)^{10}\\\\
1.64&=\left(1+r\right)^{10}\\
\sqrt[10]{1.64}&=1+r\\
1.0507&=1+r\\
1.0507-1&=r\\
0.0507&=r\\
5.07\%&=r
\end{aligned}$$

Thus we have the interest rate as $5.07\%$
Therefore, it can be concluded that the First Complex bank will have to offer the interest at the rate of $5.07\%$ in order to match the offer of First Simple Bank
